general_texts: Thank you for your interest in CSU Dominguez Hills! This articulation agreement displays lower-division course requirements specific to this major. Students are advised to meet with an academic counselor when planning to transfer to CSU Dominguez Hills and refer to the University Catalog to learn more about this major and its features. Detailed admissions requirements for transfer students are available on the CSUDH campus website. Completion of Statutory Requirements (United States History, Constitution and American Ideals) is a baccalaureate degree requirement for the California State University system and may be met prior to transfer with eligible California Community College (CCC) courses designated as US-1, US-2, and US-3. Completion of Statutory Requirements prior to transfer is most advantageous and strongly encouraged as a number of CCC courses that meet this requirement might also double-count for General Education.
ELECTIVES: Refer to the catalog for a complete list of elective courses.

Thank you for your interest in CSU Dominguez Hills! This articulation agreement displays lower-division course requirements specific to the major. Students are advised to seek advisement from a counselor when planning to transfer to CSU Dominguez Hills and refer to the University Catalog to learn more about this major and its features. Statutory Requirements/American Institutions(AI): Completion of American Institutions (U.S. Constitution, U.S. American History, and California State and local government) is a baccalaureate degree requirement for the California State University system. This requirement may be met prior to transfer with eligible California Community College (CCC) courses designated as US-1, US-2, and US-3 (see your community college's Transferability List for CSU AI courses). Completion of American Institutions prior to transfer is most advantageous and strongly encouraged, as a number of CCC AI courses may also double-count for General Education.
Language Requirement: CSUDH offers Japanese. Courses in other Asian Pacific languages are subject to approval by the program coordinator.

general_texts: Thank you for your interest in CSU Dominguez Hills! This articulation agreement displays lower-division course requirements specific to this major. Students are advised to meet with an academic counselor when planning to transfer to CSU Dominguez Hills and refer to the University Catalog to learn more about this major and its features. Detailed admissions requirements for transfer students are available on the CSUDH campus website. Completion of Statutory Requirements (United States History, Constitution and American Ideals) is a baccalaureate degree requirement for the California State University system and may be met prior to transfer with eligible California Community College (CCC) courses designated as US-1, US-2, and US-3. Completion of Statutory Requirements prior to transfer is most advantageous and strongly encouraged as a number of CCC courses that meet this requirement might also double-count for General Education.

The B.A. in Audio Engineering at CSUDH is a hands-on, professionally-oriented program geared for students who want marketable job skills for careers in studio recording, live sound reinforcement, and sound design for television, film, and live theatre. Students interested in pursuing professional careers in the highly-competitive audio engineering industry should be aware that those who succeed in establishing a career in the industry are characteristically hard-working, disciplined, focused on a career, and most of all, resilient to persevere in the face of continuous rejection.


Preparation

There are no specific lower division courses recommended for this major; however, any experience with software programs such as Pro Tools, Logic, Reason, Photoshop, Illustrator, and Audition would be helpful. Strong computer skills are a definite advantage in this field. Additionally, students familiar with computer software such as the Adobe Creative Suite will find these skills essential in the rapidly changing world of media production and delivery.

The Biophysics program will train future professionals to research the physical and chemical aspects of biological phenomena, applying their knowledge of physics to the study of biological systems. This program has two options:


  • Option 1: Research Focus. This option provides research training to students.
  • Option 2: Professional Focus. This option is designed to prepare students for the healthcare industry. BIO 220 Molecular Biology is required for this option. Articulation varies by campus.

The English Education Option satisfies Subject Matter Preparation Program in English (SMPP) requirements. The SMPP is designed for students interested in a career in teaching English at the secondary school level (grades 6-12). This program satisfies the requirements set by the California Commission on Teacher Credentialing for demonstrating substantive preparation in the subject matter field of English. Completion of this approved program or passing a comprehensive examination in English fulfills one part of the requirements leading to the Single Subject teaching Credential in English. All English Education Option students must select one of the following Extended Studies:


  • Communications - Lower division required courses: COM 250
  • Literature
  • Teaching English as a Second Language - Lower division required course: ENG 210
  • Theatre Arts - No lower division required courses


See catalog for Extended Studies upper division required courses: https://catalog.csudh.edu/academics/english/english-ba/

Preparation

Students interested in pursuing professional careers in the highly-competitive television and film industry should be aware that those who succeed in establishing a career in the industry are characteristically hard-working, disciplined, focused on a career, and most of all, resilient to persevere in the face of continuous rejection. Strong writing, interpersonal, and computer skills are a definite advantage in this field. Additionally, students familiar with the internet and other online information services will find these skills essential in the rapidly changing world of media production and delivery. There are no recommended lower division courses for this major; however, any experience with software programs such as Photoshop, Illustrator, After Effects, Premiere, Audition, or Avid would be helpful.

Completion of Statutory Requirements (United States History, Constitution and American Ideals) is a baccalaureate degree requirement for the California State University system and may be met prior to transfer with eligible California Community College (CCC) courses designated as US-1, US-2, and US-3. Completion of Statutory Requirements prior to transfer is most advantageous and strongly encouraged as a number of CCC courses that meet this requirement might also double-count for General Education.

To receive certification of Subject Matter Competency in Social Sciences for credentialing, students will be required to maintain a 2.85 GPA in the major with a C or better in all courses. Completion of the History/Social Science Education Option degree with a GPA of 2.85 or better satisfies the California Teacher Credentialing Commissions subject matter competency requirement, enabling graduates to enter post-baccalaureate teacher credential programs without completing the CSET exam in social science.

majors.major: Interdisciplinary Studies B.A. American Studies Concentration
general_texts: Thank you for your interest in CSU Dominguez Hills! This articulation agreement displays lower-division course requirements specific to this major. Students are advised to meet with an academic counselor when planning to transfer to CSU Dominguez Hills and refer to the University Catalog to learn more about this major and its features. Detailed admissions requirements for transfer students are available on the CSUDH campus website. Completion of Statutory Requirements (United States History, Constitution and American Ideals) is a baccalaureate degree requirement for the California State University system and may be met prior to transfer with eligible California Community College (CCC) courses designated as US-1, US-2, and US-3. Completion of Statutory Requirements prior to transfer is most advantageous and strongly encouraged as a number of CCC courses that meet this requirement might also double-count for General Education.

Interdisciplinary Studies (IDS)/PACE offers major concentrations in four areas of study:


  • AMERICAN STUDIES focuses on the study of the United States through an examination of history, literature, sociology, and politics.
  • COMPARATIVE STUDIES focuses on an examination of world cultures from an interdisciplinary perspective.
  • ENVIRONMENTAL STUDIES focuses on understanding the natural world and the implications of individual, community, and government actions on the environment.
  • GLOBAL STUDIES focuses on the critical knowledge of world political, economic, social, cultural, and ecological systems.


IDS is part of a national network of Programs for Accelerated College Education (PACE) that are designed for working, adult students who want to earn a bachelors degree in a reasonable period of time while they maintain a full-time job. While all admitted students are welcome, IDS/PACE students are primarily transfers who enter CSUDH with 60 units and junior-class standing. While an associate of arts degree before entering IDS/PACE is not necessary, students are advised to complete most lower division General Education requirements before transferring.


Applicants will qualify for admission to IDS/PACE if they have completed 60 transferable semester units, have a grade point average of "C" (2.0) or better and have completed the General Education Basic Skills courses (The "Golden Four," Speech, Composition, Critical Thinking, and a transferable math course) with grades of "C-" or better. The maximum number of transferable units from a community college is 70 semester units. Always check the University Catalog for current transfer requirements.


For additional information about the IDS program, please click here.

The Latinx Journalism Concentration is designed to empower students to become skilled storytellers from, for, and about Latinx communities in the U.S., while upholding the highest standards of journalistic integrity and ethics. Proficiency in Spanish is emphasized, enabling students to effectively communicate with Spanish-speaking sources and audiences.


The academic standards of the department require that all Journalism majors pass all required and prerequisite courses with grades of C or better.


Spanish Language Courses

Students take intermediate Spanish courses (SPA 220 and SPA 221) as needed.


High School & Community College Spanish Courses: Those who have completed two, three or four years of high-school Spanish or any community college Spanish will be placed in the appropriate semester of college Spanish in consultation with a departmental advisor.


Advance Placement Exams: Students may get credit for some of these courses through the Advanced Placement Examination in either Language or Literature, and/or by transferring equivalent courses from other institutions. Students who get credit for SPA 220 and/or SPA 221 through the Advanced Placement Examination or transfer credits will, in lieu, take SPA 280.

Auditions: As an unimpacted department, acceptance auditions are currently not required. Incoming music majors should come prepared to meet or exceed the performance technical requirements of accredited music degrees on the students primary instrument, such as proficiency in the 12 major and minor scales. A placement audition is required for placement into the Music Liberal Arts option, Music Education option, or Bachelor of Music degree at California State University, Dominguez Hills. During the audition students will also be considered for scholarship awards.


Lower Division Ensemble Requirement: Students are required to complete a lower division ensemble course at the 100-level and 200-level in a fall semester and a spring semester. 100-level ensembles are to be chosen from: MUS 167, 168, 169, 170, 171, 172, 173, 175, 176, 177, and 178.


Additional Program information may be found in the Music Student Handbook 2024-2025.

The Bachelor of Music degree is a professional degree that prepares students for a variety of diverse careers in music. According to the National Association of Schools of Music, the national accrediting organization, the B.M. is a professional degree in which students are expected to develop the knowledge, skills, concepts, and sensitivities essential to the professional life of the musician. To fulfill various professional responsibilities, the musician must exhibit not only technical competence, but also broad knowledge of music and music literature, the ability to integrate musical knowledge and skills sensitive to musical styles, and an insight into the role of music in intellectual and cultural life.

general_texts: Thank you for your interest in CSU Dominguez Hills! This articulation agreement displays lower-division course requirements specific to this major. Students are advised to meet with an academic counselor when planning to transfer to CSU Dominguez Hills and refer to the University Catalog to learn more about this major and its features. Detailed admissions requirements for transfer students are available on the CSUDH campus website. Completion of Statutory Requirements (United States History, Constitution and American Ideals) is a baccalaureate degree requirement for the California State University system and may be met prior to transfer with eligible California Community College (CCC) courses designated as US-1, US-2, and US-3. Completion of Statutory Requirements prior to transfer is most advantageous and strongly encouraged as a number of CCC courses that meet this requirement might also double-count for General Education.

Placement/Proficiency Exams

Placement examinations are not graded as pass/fail but are designed to determine ones placement in courses within the Department of Music.


Music Theory

Student must demonstrate a level of knowledge of music theory appropriate to undertake upper division study in music. These skills include the ability to decode both pitch and rhythmic notation in all clefs, the ability to construct and recognize major, minor, and modal scales, knowledge of proper four-part diatonic voice leading.


Musicianship

The Musicianship Placement Exam requires students to demonstrate a level of musicianship skills appropriate for a university graduate majoring in music. These skills include sight-reading, dictation, and aural comprehension of the common elements of musicrhythm, melody, harmony, timbre, texture and dynamics.  


Piano (as needed)

Every graduating student in Music Liberal Arts and Performance will be required to pass a piano proficiency examination or have record of completing Piano I and Piano II.


For more information please refer to the Music Student Handbook.

The Music Liberal Arts Option is intended for students who wish to pursue a liberal arts degree with a concentration in music, but who dont wish to prepare for a career as a professional performer or educator.

During the audition students will also be considered for scholarship awards.


Lower Division Ensemble Requirement: Students are required to complete a lower division ensemble course at the 100-level and 200-level in a fall semester and a spring semester. 100-level ensembles are to be chosen from: MUS 167, 168, 169, 170, 171, 172, 173, 175, 176, 177, and 178.

The B.S. in Nursing program (BSN) is for Registered Nurses or students nearing the completion of their Associate Degree in Nursing Program (ADN) at a regionally accredited institution, who are seeking a Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN). This is not a program to become a nurse. The RN to BSN program prepares registered nurses as generalists in professional nursing practice. Graduates are equipped to function as leaders, managers and resource persons in a variety of health care settings.


ADMISSIONS REQUIREMENTS


  • Sixty (60) or more transferable college semester units (70 semester units/ 105 quarter units maximum accepted from community colleges and 96 semester units from a four-year institution).
  • Current RN Licensure in the United States or transcripts noting you/the student is near the end of the program.
  • College GPA of at least 2.0; a 2.5 GPA is required for second baccalaureate applicants.
  • Completion of PREQUISITES FOR THE MAJOR including SCIENCE PREQUISITES with a minimum grade of C or better in each course.


SCIENCE PREQUISITES - Transfer students, please consult with an academic counselor from the college you are currently attending for assistance with course selection if needed. Lecture and corresponding lab must be completed at the same institution.

Complete the following:

  1. Chemistry: general, inorganic, organic or integrated with associated lab (4-5 units) approved for Cal-GETC AREAS 5A & 5C or CSU GE AREAS B1 & B3
  2. Human Anatomy with Lab (4 units) approved for Cal-GETC AREAS 5B & 5C or CSU GE AREAS B2 & B3
  3. Human Physiology with Lab (4 units) approved for Cal-GETC AREAS 5B & 5C or CSU GE AREAS B2 & B3
  4. Microbiology with lab (4 units) approved for Cal-GETC AREAS 5B & 5C or CSU GE AREAS B2 & B3


  • GE Certification from a California Community College prior to admission is recommended.
  • Students may apply to the University in the third or fourth semester of their Associate Degree Program.
  • Licensure is required before enrollment in Community Health and Leadership & Management classes. United States RN licensure must be unencumbered, unrestricted, with no probation or disciplinary action pending or imposed.
  • For additional information about program admission requirements, please click here.

The Bachelor of Science in Organizational Leadership Studies (OLS) program (formerly known as the Applied Studies [APS] BS) is a specially designed online degree program that meets the needs of diverse students who have significant work experience and/or have made progress toward or achieved associate degrees that they may readily transfer to pursue upper-division coursework. This program emphasizes workplace applications of academic subjects enabling students to obtain a Bachelor of Science degree with advanced coursework preparing them for management and/or leadership roles in their professions. The interdisciplinary curriculum is particularly suited for individuals with backgrounds or degrees in technical fields for which there is no apparent bachelors program into which they may readily transfer and pursue upper division coursework.


Preparation for the major: It is recommended to have significant lower-division courses and/or general education courses completed (minimum 60 semester or equivalent units) prior to admission. Most potential students will come with an associate degree or the equivalent completed. Up to 18 units of lower-division technical coursework may be integrated as a part of the degree program. Work experience, while highly desirable, is not specifically required for admission to the Organizational Leadership Studies degree program.

Students are advised to meet with an academic counselor when planning to transfer to CSU Dominguez Hills and refer to the University Catalog to learn more about this major and its features. Detailed admissions requirements for transfer students are available on the CSUDH campus website. Completion of Statutory Requirements (United States History, Constitution and American Ideals) is a baccalaureate degree requirement for the California State University system and may be met prior to transfer with eligible California Community College (CCC) courses designated as US-1, US-2, and US-3. Completion of Statutory Requirements prior to transfer is most advantageous and strongly encouraged as a number of CCC courses that meet this requirement might also double-count for General Education.

• Students transferring from an articulating community college should have completed three semesters of calculus (through differential and integral calculus of several variables), two semesters of calculus-based physics and one semester of general chemistry. If those students have not had an introduction to modern physics and/or mathematical physics, they must take PHY 134 and PHY 306 as soon as possible upon arrival at CSUDH.

Completion of Statutory Requirements (United States History, Constitution and American Ideals) is a baccalaureate degree requirement for the California State University system and may be met prior to transfer with eligible California Community College (CCC) courses designated as US-1, US-2, and US-3. Completion of Statutory Requirements prior to transfer is most advantageous and strongly encouraged as a number of CCC courses that meet this requirement might also double-count for General Education.

• There are no lower division course requirements for this major; however, as a preparation for the major, lower division courses introducing students to the discipline of political science, international relations and comparative politics also are highly recommended.
  • Students at CSU Dominguez Hills should complete both POL 100 and 101 as a preparation for the major. POL 100 satisfies CSU GE AREA D Social Sciences. POL 101 satisfies US-2 Constitution & Government and US-3 California State and Local Government graduation requirements.
  • Transfer students must take POL 300 (Quantitative Methods of Political Analysis) at CSUDH.

Students are advised to meet with an academic counselor when planning to transfer to CSU Dominguez Hills and refer to the University Catalog to learn more about this major and its features. Detailed admissions requirements for transfer students are available on the CSUDH campus website. Completion of Statutory Requirements (United States History, Constitution and American Ideals) is a baccalaureate degree requirement for the California State University system and may be met prior to transfer with eligible California Community College (CCC) courses designated as US-1, US-2, and US-3. Completion of Statutory Requirements prior to transfer is most advantageous and strongly encouraged as a number of CCC courses that meet this requirement might also double-count for General Education.

• The Major in Spanish provides students with a solid foundation in the Spanish language. Community college transfer students planning to take upper division Spanish courses at CSU Dominguez Hills should have completed four semesters of college level Spanish successfully. Those who have taken fewer than four semesters of Spanish in a community college will be placed at an appropriate level by means of advisement.
  • All Spanish majors must take SPA 280 at CSU Dominguez Hills. The Modern Languages Department strongly recommends those students who need additional fluency in Spanish to travel to a Spanish speaking country (under the guidance of an advisor) or to take SPA 230 Spanish Conversation (3) before or at the same time that they take SPA 280.
  • Recommended Additional Language: Those students who intend to pursue graduate work in Spanish literature or linguistics are also strongly encouraged to take a year of language other than English or Spanish.
